column1: Issy-les-Moulineaux (French pronunciation: ​[isi le mulino]) is a commune in the southwestern suburban area of Paris
column3: lying on the left bank of the river Seine. It is one of Paris' entrances and is located 6.6 km (4.1 mi) from Notre-Dame Church
column4: which is considered Kilometre zero of France. On 1 January 2010
column5: Issy-les-Moulineaux became part of the  Grand Paris Seine Ouest agglomeration community
column6: which merged into the Métropole du Grand Paris in January 2016.

column1: Issy-les-Moulineaux has successfully moved its economy from an old manufacturing base to high value-added service sectors and is at the heart of the Val de Seine business district
column2: the largest cluster of telecommunication and media businesses in France hosting the headquarters of most major French TV networks.
Issy-les-Moulineaux was simply called Issy. The name Issy comes from Medieval Latin Issiacum or Isciacum
column5: although some think the name comes from a Celtic radical meaning "under the wood". Local legend recounted on the city's official website mentions alternative origin of the name arising from a temple of the Egyptian goddess Isis said to be under the site of the Church of Saint Stephen.In 1893 Issy officially became Issy-les-Moulineaux. Les Moulineaux was the name of a hamlet on the territory of the commune
column6: apparently named Les Moulineaux due to the windmills (French: moulins) that stood there.

column1: The town was once the location of the Château d'Issy
column3: former home of the Princes of Conti. On 1 January 1860
column4: the city of Paris was enlarged by annexing neighboring communes. On that occasion
column5: about a third of the commune of Issy-les-Moulineaux was annexed to Paris
column6: and forms now the neighborhood of Javel

column1: Issy-les-Moulineaux is home to a community of 5
column2: 000 Armenians that have established themselves in the area since the 1930s. The community has two Armenian churches
column5: a monument dedicated to the Armenian Genocide
column6: and a street named after Armenia called Rue d'Armenie
column7: and Rue d'Erevan named after Armenia's capital Yerevan. Issy-les-Moulineaux became twin cities with Echmiadzin

column2: an expansive field in Issy had been dedicated to military exercises. This land
column4: was made into an airfield in the 1900s during the pioneering era of aviation. Issy-les-Moulineaux soon became a hot spot for aviation in France
column5: the most active airfield in Paris
column6: and the site of many flight experiments. Photographers
column7: newspaper reporters and intelligence agents from other countries gathered there to report on developments.The airfield of Issy-les-Moulineaux was the starting point of the 1911 Paris to Madrid air race. One of the competing planes crashed into the audience during take-off
column8: killing the French Minister of War Henri Maurice Berteaux. It hosted the trap shooting events for the 1924 Summer Olympics.The firm of Appareils d'Aviation Les Frères Voisin
column9: the world's first commercial airplane factory (1908) which was initially located in Boulogne-Billancourt
column10: transformed itself into a luxury automobile manufacturing company named Avions Voisin in 1920. Most of Voisin's manufacturing facilities were then relocated in neighboring Issy-les-Moulineaux. Avions Voisin closed its doors in 1940.

column1: The last fixed wing flight occurred in 1953
column2: after which the aerodrome handled only helicopters; it continues to do this
column3: with the ICAO code LFPI. It is operated by Aéroports de Paris.

column1: Issy-les-Moulineaux is served by two stations on Paris Métro Line 12: Corentin Celton and Mairie d'Issy
column2: two stations on Paris RER line C: Issy–Val de Seine and Issy and three stations on Île-de-France tramway Line 2: Les Moulineaux
column3: Jacques-Henri Lartigue and Issy–Val de Seine. Multiple RATP bus lines have stops or their arrival/departure station in the city.
